Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Impacts of Projected Climate Change on Physiological Performance of Coral Reef Fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Increased sea temperatures and decreased ocean pH due to human induced climate change will have both direct and indirect impacts on marine life. This project is designed to investigate variation in the physiological responses of reef fish to projected end-of-the-century environmental conditions. Temperature is perhaps the most significant abiotic factor influencing the performance and fitness of marine organisms and decreased pH, or ocean acidification, has been shown to impose trade offs to fish between behavioral and physiological performance. Such research will help scientists to better understand how climate change might impact population dynamics and the long term viability of economically valuable species. This study will be a collaborative effort between the fellow and Dr. Jodie Rummer of James Cook University in Queensland, Australia. Dr. Rummer is a leading expert in fish physiology and behavior at the ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies, an international hub of tropical research.

To investigate how the physiology of particular reef associated fish species are impacted by increasing temperature and ocean acidification, this project will quantify the changes to various aspects of fish metabolism and swimming performance following sustained exposure to realistic, near future climate conditions. The results from this EAPSI award will, in part, contribute to knowledge of species-specific, whole organism responses to changing environmental conditions and will identify potential mechanisms underlying altered performance. Fish play key roles in marine food webs and are a valuable source of protein for humans. As a consequence, information linking individual performance to population and community scale dynamics will help shape marine management strategies to ensure the persistence of coral reef biodiversity in a rapidly changing world.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During my time in Dr. Rummer’s lab, I gained hands-on experience in both the lab and field with several research techniques aimed at answering questions regarding the physiology and behavior of reef fishes and sharks in response to predicted climate change conditions on the Great Barrier Reef (GBR). This lab’s research focus aims to address one of the most significant gaps in our current understanding of the effects of changing environmental conditions on the population dynamics and long-term persistence of marine organisms – the links between individual physiological state and ecological performance. The research I was able to be a part of during my fellowship will provide critical information with which to make predictions about the future viability of valuable marine resources. This learn-by-doing experience in both the lab and field were extraordinary opportunities for me as a current MS student in a temperate rocky shore lab with limited experience with subtidal research. The EAPSI program allowed me to gain a thoughtful perspective on how researchers look at current problems the GBR faces and how the results we obtain from the lab’s projects might be used to influence decisions affecting the its future management. I now have experience with several different, specific research protocols and am familiar with the appropriate data analyses that follow: (1) systematically examining larval fish gill structure (histological techniques), (2) measuring critical thermal maxima for juvenile reef sharks, and (3) quantifying reef fish behaviour in response to predator cues. In addition to these explicit experiences, I also met with other PhD students in the Rummer lab to learn about what kinds of overall questions the lab asks and why, as well as the conceptual framework behind their reasoning and specific approaches to answering those questions. Those 8 weeks were particularly valuable for me as I plan to pursue a PhD after I complete my MS and am interested in switching from invertebrate models to vertebrates; perhaps doing so specifically at my host campus, James Cook University. I was able to learn about the logistics involved with conducting research on vertebrates (e.g., animal ethics permits, fish husbandry in aquaria, etc.), while getting to know the campus, marine facilities, lab spaces, and most importantly, the faculty. Thanks to Dr. Rummer and her students, I was able to set up meetings with 5 other research advisors to learn about their individual labs, research interests, and what skills and abilities they looked for when evaluating PhD candidates. From these meetings I was able to find 3 potential advisors with whom to apply to JCU’s doctoral program in the ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies (CoECRS). Lastly, from working alongside the Rummer lab specifically, my work at JCU led to an additional international collaboration in Mo’orea, French Polynesia that occurred the following January where I continued gaining hands-on field experience in a similar tropical ecosystem gathering data on juvenile reef sharks.

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2017
Modified by: Elizabeth A Duncan
